author: @adithyan_ai
text: Hey Corey and other fellow learners,  I have a follow-up question. So, what other resources would you recommend after this course? By following your tutorial, I am already able to build a simple website for my neighbor's clinic. What I learned here was enough for this purpose.  But, I want to learn more. Especially, I am video encoding/processing/packaging backend engineer. I have many cool ideas around this field. I want to build a website with fancy UI that will expose, some video processing capabilities to end-users. Example: Upscale your videos to 4k using ML, Auto-caption your videos, among others.  I clearly know how to solve this in the backend (some python scripts, c++ code, and so on).   My question is, along with flask now, what else should I learn to build a really functional and aesthetically nice-looking "frontend"? Do you recommend a framework? Any other tutorials that I can follow?  And advice would be hugely helpful.  Best, Adi

author: @zebusaqua4415
text: If you want to add and expand to the project. Say add more form fields to a post. You will run into a issue with the database. In order to solve this you have to remove your site.db file from your project back it up just in case. Add in to your __init__ file at the end just before return.  app with app.app_context():         db.create_all()   this will make a new blank db and add in the stuff you put in your models.py   I hope i explained this well enough.

author: @davidderksen7976
text: Hi Corey, thank you for your series about Flask!, i have some question about query in the command line. I finished all the video's in the tutorial but if i follow the steps from previous tutorials, i get a error. I go to my project folder in the command line and type 'from appname import create_app()' ->  app = create_app() -> from veb.models import User -> User.query.all() i get this error:   Traceback (most recent call last):   File "PATH\Python\Python37-32\lib\site-packages\sqlalchemy\util\_collections.py", line 999, in __call__     return self.registry[key] KeyError: 8156  During handling of the above exception, another exception occurred:  Traceback (most recent call last):   File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>   File "PATH\Python\Python37-32\lib\site-packages\flask_sqlalchemy\__init__.py", line 514, in __get__     return type.query_class(mapper, session=self.sa.session())   File "PATH\Python\Python37-32\lib\site-packages\sqlalchemy\orm\scoping.py", line 74, in __call__     return self.registry()   File "PATH\Python\Python37-32\lib\site-packages\sqlalchemy\util\_collections.py", line 1001, in __call__     return self.registry.setdefault(key, self.createfunc())   File "PATH\Python\Python37-32\lib\site-packages\sqlalchemy\orm\session.py", line 2950, in __call__     return self.class_(**local_kw)   File "PATH\Python\Python37-32\lib\site-packages\flask_sqlalchemy\__init__.py", line 141, in __init__     self.app = app = db.get_app()   File "PATH\Python\Python37-32\lib\site-packages\flask_sqlalchemy\__init__.py", line 912, in get_app     'No application found. Either work inside a view function or push' RuntimeError: No application found. Either work inside a view function or push an application context. See http://flask-sqlalchemy.pocoo.org/contexts/.  Thank you for helping! The complete app works and did everything what i needed to do in your tutorials.

author: @soumitripattnaik
text: First of all I want to take a moment to THANK YOU for putting your time and effort to make this series.  I started out learning Python around six months back. Before that I was writing code (professionally and personally) in Java for the better part of last 7 years. Like God's gift, I came across this channel few months back and started with the Python fundamentals series. Then one series led to another and six months after, today I code in Python at work (after almost 5 years of coding in Java professionally) and feel very passionately about it doing it and learning it.   I feel, the way you teach is the way programming should be taught. You have the perfect examples, the best explanation, great preparation and quality direction in your videos. I have recommended your channel to a number of my friends and colleagues and everyone has thanked me for that. Got to say that, you have a rare quality of connecting to a very diverse audience.   Even tough, I had started learning django couple of times, I could never finish the courses due to lack of all of the things that you excel at in those courses. However, I had no intention of learning Flask. But today after finish all the videos in this series I feel like great. I know, all these sound cheesy, but I feel, I had to THANK YOU.

author: @TheGreenCheeseMoon
text: Here's a short guide for demoing this on your local PC (windows specifically since that's what I use for my main desktop)  pip install flask flask-bcrypt flask-mail pillow  git clone https://github.com/CoreyMSchafer/code_snippets  run this in cmd to set the environment variables real quick: SET SECRET_KEY=5791628bb0b13ce0c676dfde280ba245 SET SQLALCHEMY_DATABASE_URI=sqlite:///site.db note that this only sets the variables within the context of that cmd session.  cd into code_snippets\Python\Flask_Blog\12-Error-Pages and run 'python run.py'
